completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE REHNQUIST
completeLines.speech: We'll hear argument first this morning in No. 02-1824, Doug Dretke v. Michael Wayne Haley.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: This case concerns the continuing vitality of the procedural default rule, an important bulwark to federalism, comity, and finality of judgments. This Court has consistently maintained that cause and prejudice can address problems with procedural default, and that the actual innocence exception should be applicable only in exceedingly rare cases.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Can -- can you tell me -- I don't want to derail the argument -- you've conceded that this sentence is unlawful?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Yes, Justice Kennedy.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, then why are you here? Don't -­ is there some rule that you can't confess error in your state or?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: No, Justice Kennedy, but the state is here, because the state is concerned about the impact on the procedural default rule, in particular the Fifth Circuit's decision.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, so a man does 15 years so you can vindicate your legal point in some other case? I -- I just lower the sentence.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Implicit in the procedural default -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And I'd say the same for the Government of the United States.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Implicit in the procedural default rule is the premise that petitioner has a valid claim. In -- in some ways this case, as the Fifth Circuit remarked, as the judges dissenting from denial of rehearing en banc, in some ways this case presents an usually pristine form, I mean, it's almost a law school hypothetical, because the error is so clean. There's a 3-day disparity -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: At -- at the prisoner's expense.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: But that is inherent in any claim with procedural default.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: No, but it's not a -- it's not a -- as if there's some new trial and -- and it's in doubt. It's very clear he should not be in jail for, like what, 12, 14, 15 more years.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: It is very clear that there was an error, and that if Mr. Haley had raised the error at trial, that the trail judge would have and should have sustained -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But is it -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- not also very clear that he's going years in jail?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: It is clear that he will spend 10 years in jail when he had an objection he could have raised that he did not.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, I understand that, but -- but if the law were followed and everything went perfectly, he would spend less than 2 or -- what is it, 2 or 3 years?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Two years would be the max.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And he's going to spend 16 years in jail, is that right?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Yes, Justice Stevens.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Now, is that just, do you think?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Maintaining the procedural default rule is --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I understand that you want to preserve the procedures, but do you think justice is being done?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: I think justice is being done because he had a full and fair trial and an opportunity to raise his errors, and there's no greater -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, let me ask you this. Why -- why isn't there still an inadequate assistance of counsel claim out there, and why shouldn't the court address that before it gets into the question that it dealt with?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Justice O'Connor, I think there is a counsel.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, why don't we vacate and remand and let them deal with that?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Justice O'Connor, I think that is something that is open to the Court to do and I think that is one of the fundamental problems with what the district court did.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: You don't think that that claim was waived here? You don't urge us to make that finding, do you?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: There is an argument that it was waived, but I think the Fifth Circuit -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, except the court below didn't decide that question.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: And I think the Fifth Circuit could certainly deem the petitioner's pleading sufficient to preserve that claim.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Yeah, I would think so too. I can't -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Are you saying you won't -- you won't argue a waiver if it's sent back?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: If it's sent back, we would be prepared to address the ineffective assistance claim on its merits.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And not raise any procedural impediment to -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: The -- the -- another feature of this case, what makes it so disturbing, is that the initial error was the prosecutors, in -- when the prosecutor indicted him, that indictment was incorrect, and then the rest followed, relying on that original mistake of the prosecutor. So it seems a -- really an ideal case for the prosecution to say, we missed it, and then as a result of we -- what we, the prosecutor missed, the court missed it, defense counsel missed it, but it was our error and we should correct it.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: And, Justice Ginsburg, this case may well, if the Court finds ineffective assistance, that would suffice to correct this, because ineffective assistance counts as cause, and in many ways this case illustrates why cause and prejudice is ample to address error in sentencing in non-capital sentencing and why there's not a need to open the door to a new category of exceptions to procedural default.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, this defendant certainly raised -­ he raised the point in his pro se petition in the state court and he raised it in the Federal court, the ineffective assistance, but nobody paid any attention to him.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: The -- the claim was denied in state habeas and the Federal habeas court did not address it because it had already granted relief based upon his claim that he was actually innocent of the sentence.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Did the prosecutor suggest that maybe the court should have dealt with it, because neither court gave any reason for rejecting that claim?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: I -- the -- the district court jumped ahead in the process. Rather than address cause and prejudice, the district court said that it didn't need to address cause and prejudice because it found actual innocence, and that's one of the -- the significant problems, much like statutory interpretation, where a court should -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Mr. Cruz, let me -- let me make -- get clear what -- what -- what your position is. You're -- you'd be totally content if we don't resolve this question that's before us about whether whenever there's a procedural default that has clearly resulted and -- and with no ineffective assistance of counsel, that has clearly resulted in an injustice, you know, we -- we throw away all the procedural rules. You -- you don't want us to address that and just send it back and say, well, before you get to that question, you have to resolve the cause and prejudice and then leave -- leave dangling in the air the question, the significant question, it seems to me, on which we granted cert?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, the first preference of split and to clarify that there is no actual innocence exception to non-capital sentencing. If the Court is not inclined to do so, the State of Texas, our second preferred outcome is to vacate the decision of the Fifth Circuit so we don't operate under that precedent.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Why should we -- why should we not be inclined to do so? Is it a constitutional question that we shouldn't reach? I mean, do we have to do a sort of jurisprudential striptease and decide this one case, leaving open this question? I don't understand why we wouldn't decide it.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: And Texas is not urging the Court not to decide it. It is simply saying that is an avenue should the Court decide to decide -- to rule on this case in a more narrow ground, that is an avenue that would provide some relief to Texas because it would vacate the Fifth Circuit decision and it would allow ultimately for some relief for Mr. Haley as well.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: So you come back and fight another day?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Well, or perhaps someone else would fight in a different circuit.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But if the court views this as a preliminary question, a question that the Fifth Circuit and any other Federal court should have reached logically before it reached the question on which it decided the case -­

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Yes, Justice -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- then we should put the court back in the position that it should have been in if it handled the case correctly.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Justice Ginsburg, we certainly agree that as a matter of thinking through procedural default, that courts should begin with cause and prejudice, that the actual innocence exception as a potential trump card should not be jumped to first.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, that just means it made two mistakes. Number one, if this theory that you're opposing did exist, it shouldn't have reached it first, okay? It should have reached it second. Mistake one. And number two, according to you, is this theory doesn't exist anyway.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: And -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I don't see why it's more intelligent for us to reach the first question than the second if -- if there isn't any such thing as number one and number two. If the only one that exists is number one, it seems to me we should say so.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: And, Justice Scalia, I agree entirely with your characterization of the errors made by the court below.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: May I ask this question? I always procedural default rule, and as I understand it, the Government concedes there was injustice at the end of their brief. They say it's less significant, it's a less -­ qualitatively less significance than if you put an innocent man to death. But is it not manifest that there was injustice in this case?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Justice Stevens, I -- I do not believe it is. It -- it is manifest that there was error -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, can you give me an example of when manifest injustice would exist other than a death case?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: There are a host of instances in which this Court has held that actual constitutional errors should nonetheless not be addressed because the defendant has procedurally defaulted that.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, I understand that, but is there any -- any content to the manifest injustice exception in your view?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Absolutely there is. The paradigmatic case -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, give me an example.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: -- is an individual was is innocent of the crime.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, he's innocent of the crime he's in -- in prison for. technical of legal sense. In the ordinary sense of the word, he committed the theft, he committed the predicate felonies -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: No, but if the law were followed, he would have been released a long time ago, would he not?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: If he had raised his objection.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: What -- what actually -- what was he charged with, Mr. Cruz? What was the substantive offense and what were the recidivist offenses?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: He was charged with theft, and that was enhanced to a state jail felony because he had committed two prior thefts. And then upon sentencing, his sentence was aggravated because he was a habitual offender and had two prior felony convictions. Now, the indictment alleged that they were sequential and it turned out that allegation was incorrect.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: They -- they were sequential. I mean, one followed another. Isn't what it comes down to is that he should have been -- he should have been given this longer sentence for the second theft instead of for the third theft?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: No, actually, Justice Scalia, the way the statute reads -­ theft that -- that was used for recidivism occurred 3 days after, right, the --

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: It's a 3 -- it's a 3-day disparity. The first crime was delivery of amphetamines.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Yeah.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: And he committed that in 1988, but that conviction did not become final until October 18th, 1991. Three days before October 18th, 1991, he committed attempted robbery, and the way the Texas statute reads, he has to commit the second felony after the first felony conviction becomes final.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But why did the first felony take so long to become final? It took -- you say it took 3 years?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: It -- it did. I don't know the extent to which that was discovery in the trial, but that -- that's ultimately what the record reveal in terms of when that conviction -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: At -- at trial, do you think the prosecutor would have, if he had noted this error, have the duty to call the attention of the trial judge before the trial judge imposed sentence?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Absolutely, absolutely. And -- and -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But the trial obligation -- the trial lawyer's obligation to do justice is -- is somehow missing

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: The state has an obligation to be candid with the court, so at any point in which the state became aware of this error, the state would be obliged to inform the court, but that's a very different thing to say that when there is a procedural default, when the defendant has not preserved his error, that the state should not act to vindicate that procedural default. There is an important value in protecting the procedural rules in the State of Texas, and that value is not served. I mean, ultimately, this Court has said that the very narrow exception of actual innocence should apply in very narrow circumstances. So this Court has ultimately engaged in a balancing, a balancing that derives from prior language in the -- in the Federal habeas -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, narrow circumstances, when the record makes it perfectly clear that an error has been committed and an innocent person is in jail, that's -- what more do you need?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: The difficult -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: There aren't many cases like this.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: It is true that there are not many cases where the state concedes error, but the difficulty with pivoting the test on that is the basic operating premise of every habeas petition. Where procedural default is raised not hesitated to allow far more significant claims not to be addressed because of procedural default.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Yes, but usually the valid claim is some procedural error in the trial, something of that character. It's not that he's totally innocent and everybody agrees he's totally innocent.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: This -- this Court has addressed procedural default in the context of forced confessions, in the context of statements without Miranda rights, in the context of psychiatry -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But that -- but -- but -- no, what you need to satisfy Justice Stevens is -- is a case where the mistake unquestionably caused the outcome of the -­ unquestionably caused the outcome of the trial to be wrong. All of the ones you just mentioned, it may have caused it to be wrong, may not have, you don't -- the jury might have convicted him without the confession, et cetera, et cetera. Do you have any cases where -- where, as here, there is no doubt that the procedural default produced a different outcome in the trial?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: We do not have any cases like that, but that aspect simply goes to prejudice, and this Court has repeatedly cautioned that the actual innocence exception should not be used to transform cause and prejudice just to prejudice. The only question is if there was cause for not raising it, and in terms of asking -- I mean, Justice Stevens asked me about, is this a manifest injustice. There seems nothing on the face of it that is plain to me that allowing an individual to be convicted and to remain convicted and serve in jail or even be executed based on a forced confession is somehow a lesser injustice than allowing Mr. Haley to serve a sentence -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I think it's a lesser injustice if he's really guilty of the crime.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: But in this case, Mr. Haley is guilty of the theft, he's guilty of the predicate offense -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: He is not guilty of what he's in prison for.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: Only in the sense -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And I don't think the 3 days is an argument that has any merit. You'd make the same argument if it was 10 years. You'd make the same argument.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: It is -- it is true that 3 days or 5 days or whatever does not matter. What matters, and what we are urging, is that Mr. Haley had multiple avenues to challenge this. He could have challenged this at trial. He could have challenged this on direct appeal.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: If he could deliberately refuse to do it this a case of, you know, in our original case that we talk about gamesmanship and so on, do you think this is gamesmanship on his part?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: You know, we don't have reason to suggest that Mr. Haley in this instance was engaged in gamesmanship with respect to this error, but the record is susceptible to an interpretation that his counsel was engaged in gamesmanship with respect to whether or not Mr. Haley pleaded to the enhancements. Because what happened at trial is Mr. Haley's attorney urged the trial court, my client doesn't want to plead, please go ahead, he's not going to plead. The trial court did what the counsel asked and he immediately, on direct appeal that was his principal challenge, and that is one possible interpretation of the record is the counsel was attempting to sandbag. There was a line of state court cases saying it was mandatory error not to plead.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, if the counsel sandbagged for the purpose of getting a 16-year sentence instead of a 3-year sentence, doesn't that demonstrate that he was incompetent?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: It may well, and I certainly wouldn't urge that counsel engaged in good strategic decisions, but it may have been a strategic decision with respect to urging the court to commit an error under state law that caused the counsel not to notice the disparities in the enhancements.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: In one of the proceedings, Texas did take the position that there -- this was not ineffective assistance of counsel. The reply brief I think makes it clear that you're not disputing that the -- that the ineffective assistance of counsel claim is alive and well. But there was a time you took a different view.

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: That -- that is correct, and we agree at this point there is a very significant argument of ineffective assistance of counsel, and I would note that the court of criminal appeals in Texas has found ineffective assistance of counsel in almost precisely the same circumstance where a counsel failed to notice the non­ sequential nature of felonies used to enhance a habitual offender in the decision of Ex parte Scott, which is found at 581 S.W.2d 181. If there are no further questions, I'd like to reserve the balance of my time.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Very well, Mr. Cruz. Mr. Roberts, we'll hear from you.

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The actual innocence exception applies in the extraordinary case where a prisoner has been convicted of a crime that he did not commit. The Court shouldn't extend that narrow exception to the very different situation where the prisoner is guilty of the crime of which he was convicted.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, what should we do in this case with someone who -- who is serving an unjust sentence under the law?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well -- well, Your Honor, even if this Court holds that the actual innocence exception doesn't apply to non-capital sentencing, respondent may well be entitled to relief here.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: On the inadequate assistance claim?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: On the ineffective assistance claim, and I -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Do you urge that that's waived, or can the court below address it?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We don't believe that it's waived, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Thank you.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Why not go to that first and tell them to do that, because this is just very difficult, that that would be the reason? The reason it would be difficult is because actual innocence is simply a way at getting at manifest injustice, I think, and a reason that this fits in the manifest injustice is we feel differently about substantive laws that govern how long a person is going to be in prison than we do about procedural laws, and sentencing is an aspect of that. But if you take that and say, look, this is an absolute obvious case where there was just wrong sentencing, it's not actual innocence, it's wrong sentencing, but it's so obvious, it's so clear that this is just unjust. Once we're down that path, I mean, how do we draw a line between that and every sentencing error? Now, I'm just -­

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: That -- that's -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- I'm getting you to -­

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- but that's right, Your Honor -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- I know that's just what you were going to say -­

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- and that's our primary -- that's our primary concern here.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: All right. But is the answer then not to deal with it when it's clear?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, the -- the Court certainly could do that. There is a danger I think in -- in addressing the actual innocence exception in a case where there's cause and prejudice and so you don't need to address the real concern is when it's not that clear about whether somebody's actually innocent.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: So you're saying it would be wise to send it back, is that right?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: It -- it -- yes, except that, you know, certainly our -- our primary interest in the question here is in the question that's divided the circuits and in making clear that there isn't a broad actual innocence exception as applied to -- to non-capital sentencing.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Perhaps when it's clear it will always be the case that there's been ineffective assistance of counsel. How -- how could it be, you know, clear as day and ineffective assistance of counsel not -- not have intervened?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: That -- that's -- that's right, Your Honor. It may well frequently be the case, which is why you wouldn't need the actual innocence exception for that -- for that circumstance. But -- but our concern is that a rule that applies to the exception where the prisoner is guilty of the crime and is claiming only that he's suffering an excessive prison term, if taken to its logical conclusion, that would open up final judgments where a criminal defendant is belatedly claiming that a sentencing guideline was incorrectly applied to him and that he's therefore innocent of the sentence.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, suppose -- suppose this were the Federal system. Would the Department of Justice take the position that it would not ask sua sponte that this sentence be reduced?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We -- we well might not have appealed from the district court judgment in this case. If the Government takes an appeal, the Solicitor General office has to -- has to approve those appeals and we would certainly -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: That's one tremendous advantage the Government has over individual criminal defendants' lawyers, isn't it? They choose the facts they want to bring here.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, they do, don't they?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, we certainly would -- would take into account the entire situation in -- in making a determination on that, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: You think there might be some doubt that the Department of Justice would insist that -­

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I -- I hate to predict it -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- a 10 -- a 10-year -- an unlawful 10­ year term?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- in any case, but I would expect that if it was clear that there was cause and prejudice that was -- that a case involved a situation where the prisoner ­ -

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Forget cause and prejudice. Suppose the term is unlawful and it's conceded to be unlawful. Are you taking the position the Department of Justice says he has to be held anyway?

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I'm -- I'm astounded by that.

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I'm not -- I'm -- I'm not taking the position of that, Your Honor. I just -- I hesitate to -- to make a prediction about some future case where I don't know all the facts. I certainly think that if -- if, in a case like this where a prisoner was clearly entitled to -- had -­ had cause and prejudice and was entitled to relief, that we would call that to the attention of the -- of the district court or to the attention of the court of appeals.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Mr. Roberts, you now say ineffective assistance of counsel claim, I think you answered that that was preserved. But I noticed that you were very careful in your brief to say twice if -- if Haley preserved the ineffective assistance of counsel -­

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- argument.

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We -- I -- I -- we think that it's a question to be decided by the -- the court of appeals on -­ on remand, Your Honor, and the state had made arguments about whether it was preserved or not. Justice O'Connor asked me my opinion as to whether the -- whether the claim was preserved, and in -- in our view it was, but that would be a question for the lower court to -- to decide, and apparently the state is no longer arguing that -- that it wasn't preserved. As I said, our -- our -- the -- the issue that we're primarily concerned about here is a broad extension of the actual innocence exception to an erroneous prison term, and that would involve substantial societal costs, because the challenges to the findings -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Would it involve all those costs if we can find the exception to cases in which the state acknowledges the error?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, that would certainly be a far less problematic exception.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Would it be problematic if we limit it that way?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: No, Your Honor, except to the extent that it -- it extended -- extends actual innocence beyond an offense which has a special constitutional status.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Are we free to write this code of criminal procedure? I mean, I can understand all these arguments being made to, you know, to Congress or -- or to the state legislatures for writing a code of criminal

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, well, the -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- justification for this -­

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- these rules are -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- something which has never been done in -- in a couple of hundred years is -- is -- is part of due process?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: No, Your Honor. My understanding is that the actual innocence exception and the procedural default rules are court-made limitations on the jurisdiction -- on the exercise of discretion by the Federal habeas court, and so the court's exercising its -- its supervisory authority over the courts.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: No, but the Federal habeas court has to be relying upon some law to -- to undo the state conviction, right?

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Yes, Your Honor. There has to be an underlying claim.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Yeah.

completeLines.speaker: ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: But we're talking here about the actual innocence exception, which is a gateway to consideration of that underlying claim. There -- there still has to be an underlying constitutional claim, and -­ and that -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Mr. Roberts, why is it -­ the Court whether there is -- is such a claim.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION

The inquiries are altogether different. The former, what was at -- the case at common law at the time of the founding. The latter is, as the exchange illuminated, a question of what 28 U.S.C. Section 2254 provides. And I would note 2255, with respect to Federal habeas, explicitly includes in its statutory text as one of the grounds for granting habeas that a sentence is, quote, in excess of the maximum authorized by law. That's in 2255. It is not in 2254. The only ground for granting habeas in 2254 with respect to a state conviction is if someone is held in custody of violation of the laws or Constitution of the United States. And so it is altogether possible that this Court could decide at some future date to -- to overrule Almendarez-Torres and then yet nonetheless decide that in looking to the ends of justice that now repeal language from the habeas statute, that there is not an obligation to excuse procedural default for every single conceivable sentencing error.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But can I -- I just -- this is a case in which you yourself concede he shouldn't be in jail under the substantive law of Texas, and it is a case where you yourself agree there is a very big claim that the lawyer was incompetent. If we send this back, is Texas going to move to revoke his bail?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: The -- the state is willing to allow the ineffective assistance case to be litigated before proceeding to reincarcerate Mr. Haley, so we will wait until that -- that claim is resolved before -- before -­

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: He's out while it's being litigated?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: He -- he is out right now and the state will leave him out until his claim is resolved with respect to that. With respect to the balance, which is -- which is ultimately how this Court has analyzed the actual innocence exception, on the one side I would submit there is very limited need for extending the actual innocence exception to non-capital sentencing. Cause and prejudice can address situations where relief is merited, such as perhaps Mr. Haley's. On the other side, there is the risk of expanding that. Non-capital sentencing, unlike actual innocence, I didn't do it, of the crime, unlike actual innocence of death, non-capital sentencing is virtually ubiquitous. Interestingly, Mr. Haley's amici law professors in footnote 13 of their brief acknowledge the ability of the slippery slope to extend beyond just increasing the statutory maximum to sentences within a range and to a whole host of factors that the states used for sentencing factors, facts -­ factors such as the amount of drugs, such as the value of stolen goods, such as the status of a victim, whether the victim is elderly, whether the victim is a police officer.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: What has been the -- the experience in the circuits that have adopted this rule applying the actual there?

completeLines.speaker: CRUZ
completeLines.speech: There have been relatively few cases that have come up since those decisions, but I would note first of all we don't know what unpublished decisions are out there, and secondly, there's a significant difference between a circuit decision allowing an exception and a decision of this Court.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE REHNQUIST
completeLines.speech: Thank you, Mr. Cruz. The case is submitted.
